Hi Simon,

On 8/16/06, Simon Chappell <simonpeterchappell@...> wrote:=

>
>
> Generally, you get as much code as possible out of the GUI, so that
=
> the extracted code can be easily tested the old fashioned way. Domain
> (=
business) objects that are easily testable and a very thin GUI that
> is di=
fficult to test beats a thick GUI that's difficult to test.
>
> Someone els=
e will have to advise you about the best GUI testing tools.
> I've never ne=
eded to use one.


Do you mean that you released GUI software without ever =
automatically
testing the graphic part?

That's very surprising (almost unp=
rofessional :-)).

Having your business objects tested is nice, but it's th=
e easy part.  How do
you guarantee that when the user presses the "Ok" butt=
on, the program works
as expected?

On a side topic, testing GUI's is also =
a domain where TDD is very hard to
achieve, but let's keep that discussion =
in the other thread :-)

-- 
C=E9dric
http://testng.org
